questions.text: Calculate Amplitude in case of near vision of 20 cm and far point of infinity. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5D

 

Explanation:


To calculate the amplitude of accommodation, we use the formula:

 

Amplitude = 1/Near Point (in meters)

 

Calculation steps:

 

  1. Convert 20 cm to meters: 20 cm = 0.2 meters
  2. Apply the formula: 1/0.2 = 5 diopters

 

When the far point is at infinity (no refractive error), the amplitude is simply calculated by taking the inverse of the near point distance in meters.

 

Educational Objective: 


The amplitude of accommodation using the formula: 1/Near Point (in meters), with the far point at infinity resulting in a direct inverse calculation of the near point distance.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with testicular mass. Gross image is provided. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminoma

 

The gross image provided shows a well-circumscribed, homogeneous testicular mass, which is characteristic of a seminoma. Seminomas are the most common type of testicular germ cell tumors, especially in men between the ages of 30 and 40. These tumors typically appear as solid, uniform, pale or gray masses without significant areas of hemorrhage or necrosis, distinguishing them from other types of testicular cancers.

 

Seminomas are known for their good response to both chemotherapy and radiotherapy, making them relatively less aggressive compared to non-seminomatous germ cell tumors. This favorable prognosis is a key reason why recognizing a seminoma is critical in the clinical setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Testicular lymphoma generally occurs in older men, not in the typical age range of seminoma patients. It is also less likely to present as a well-circumscribed mass like the one shown in the image.

 

Option C. Choriocarcinoma: Choriocarcinoma usually presents with significant hemorrhage and necrosis, which are absent in the gross image provided. It is also associated with high levels of beta-HCG, which is a marker not typically elevated in seminoma.

 

Option D. Teratoma: Teratomas are characterized by their derivation from multiple germ layers, leading to a more heterogeneous appearance on gross examination. The mass might include elements like cartilage, bone, or even teeth, which are not seen in the image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminoma is the most likely diagnosis for a well-circumscribed, homogeneous testicular mass in a 35-year-old male. It is important to differentiate seminoma from other testicular tumors due to its relatively better prognosis and treatment response.

choices.text: Adenylyl cyclase
Guanylyl cyclase
Phospholipase C

questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/ hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenylyl cyclase

 

Explanation

 

Beta 2 receptor action leading to hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia is mediated by adenylyl cyclase.

 

Catecholamines act through beta 2 receptors and they use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system to stimulate the target tissues.

 

Cyclic AMP is synthesized from ATP by the action of the enzyme adenylyl cyclase.

 

  • Binding of the hormone to its receptor activates a G protein which, in turn, activates adenylyl cyclase
  • The resulting rise in cAMP turns on the appropriate response in the cell by either (or both):
    • Changing the molecular activities in the cytosol, often using Protein Kinase A (PKA) — a cAMP-dependent protein kinase that phosphorylates target proteins
    • Turning on a new pattern of gene transcription

 

Cyclic AMP produces one or more of the following responses:

 

  1. Contraction and relaxation of muscle fibers
  2. Alteration in the permeability of cell membrane
  3. Synthesis of substances inside the cell
  4. Secretion or release of substances by target cell
  5. Other physiological activities of the target cell

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guanylyl cyclase: Incorrect. While guanylyl cyclase also produces a cyclic nucleotide (cGMP) that acts as a second messenger, it is not involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Incorrect. Phospholipase C is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, not Gs-coupled receptors like the beta-2 receptors. It catalyzes the breakdown of phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate, which are involved in calcium signaling.

 

Option D. Phospholipase A2: Incorrect. This enzyme liberates arachidonic acid from phospholipids, leading to the production of eicosanoids (like prostaglandins and leukotrienes). It is not directly involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other hormones that use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system are:

 

  • ACTH
  • Angiotensin II
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • Glucagon
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • HCG
  • Luteinizing hormone
  • Parathyroid hormone
  • Secretin
  • Somatostatin
  • TSH
  • Vasopressin

questions.text: A patient with chronic diarrhea develops dermatitis herpetiformis. The physician altered his diet which improved his symptoms. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. The immune system mistakenly targets gluten, along with the lining of the small intestine, leading to symptoms such as chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and weight loss. One of the hallmark dermatological manifestations of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition presents as a chronic, intensely itchy rash, typically on the elbows, knees, back, and buttocks, and is caused by the deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermoepidermal junction.

 

The improvement of symptoms following the alteration of the patient’s diet to exclude gluten is a classic indicator of celiac disease. Once gluten is removed from the diet, the intestinal inflammation subsides, and symptoms, including dermatitis herpetiformis, typically improve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whipple disease: Whipple disease is a rare bacterial infection that can cause malabsorption, leading to symptoms such as diarrhea and weight loss. However, it does not typically cause dermatitis herpetiformis, nor does dietary modification alone usually lead to symptom improvement.

 

Option C. Crohn disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. However, it does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and dietary changes like removing gluten do not usually lead to the dramatic improvement seen in celiac disease.

 

Option D. Lactose intolerance: Lactose intolerance results from the inability to digest lactose, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy products. It does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and the improvement in symptoms would be related to avoiding dairy, not gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be suspected in patients presenting with chronic diarrhea and dermatitis herpetiformis, particularly when symptoms improve following a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Letulle technique

 

Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

Below image shows Letulle’s Method

 

 

Other Options:

 

Other Autopsy Techniques for Evisceration:

 

Option A. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

Below image shows Virchow’s Method

 

 

Option B. Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

Below image shows Rokitansky Method

 

 

Option C. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

Below image shows Ghon’s Method

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Letulle technique involves removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs en masse, preserving their relationships, and is preferred for infants to observe congenital abnormalities.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, PC dikshit, page 147

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

 

Hypersensitivity myocarditis

 

 

Giant cell myocarditis

 

 

Myocarditis of Chagas disease (arrow showing trypanosomes)

questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass originating within the middle ear. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

Explanation:

 

The CT scan shows a mass located on the promontory behind the tympanic membrane, which is typical of a glomus tympanicum, NOT glomus jugulare.

 

Key points:

 

  • Glomus tympanicum arises on the promontory along the course of Jacobson’s nerve (tympanic branch of IX cranial nerve).
  • It is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm.
  • It appears as a red mass behind the intact tympanic membrane, producing a pulsatile red reflex.
  • CT shows a soft tissue mass confined to the middle ear without erosion of the caroticojugular spine.
  • Glomus jugulare, in contrast, originates from the dome of the jugular bulb, grows into the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and typically erodes the caroticojugular spine (the “phelp sign”).

 

In CT image, there is no obvious erosion of the caroticojugular spine, and the mass is confined to the middle ear promontory, confirming glomus tympanicum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus jugulare: Incorrect here — because the tumour is limited to the middle ear promontory without signs of extension into the jugular bulb or jugular foramen. There is no caroticojugular spine erosion.

 

Option C. Otosclerosis: Does not appear as a mass. It causes abnormal bone deposition near the stapes, leading to conductive hearing loss but not a visible mass.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect — because the finding matches glomus tympanicum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A red mass on the promontory behind an intact tympanic membrane, with no erosion of the caroticojugular spine, indicates glomus tympanicum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: Identify the classification used and grade of the shown injury in a child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gartland’s classification Type III

 

The X-ray provided shows a Supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which is classified using the Gartland classification system. The Gartland classification is specifically for supracondylar fractures, particularly in children.

 

  • Gartland Type III refers to a completely displaced fracture, with no cortical contact between the fragments. There may be either medial or lateral displacement, as seen in this case.
  • The Salter-Harris classification is used for epiphyseal plate injuries, not for supracondylar fractures. Therefore, it is not applicable in this scenario.

 

To summarize:

 

  • Gartland Type I: Undisplaced fracture.
  • Gartland Type II: Displaced fracture with the posterior cortex intact.
  • Gartland Type III: Displaced fracture with no cortical contact (either medial or lateral displacement).
  • Gartland Type IV: An intraoperative diagnosis where the periosteum is damaged both anteriorly and posteriorly, requiring more complex reduction techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salter-Harris classification Type III: Incorrect because the injury in question is not an epiphyseal fracture. Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate fractures, not supracondylar fractures.

 

Option C. Gartland’s classification Type IV: Incorrect because Gartland Type IV is an intraoperative diagnosis, which is not apparent in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Salter-Harris classification Type IV: Again, incorrect because this classification system pertains to epiphyseal injuries, and the X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar humerus fractures in children, while the Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate (epiphyseal) fractures.

 

Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus

 

  • Type 1: Undisplaced
  • Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact
  • Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM)
  • Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL)
  • Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)

 

 

Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries

 

  • Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip
  • Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign)
  • Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split
  • Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis,  (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis
  • Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays

questions.text: A female patient with a BMI of 35 kg/m2 presents to you with a skin lesion in the axilla as shown below. Which of the following condition is she most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic syndrome

 

  • The skin lesion shown in the image of axilla with velvety textured skin is indicative of Acanthosis nigricans. In this case, the patient is most likely suffering from Metabolic syndrome based on the diagnosis.

 

Acanthosis nigricans

  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism:

  • Hypothyroidism primarily manifests with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, bradycardia, alopecia and dry skin. It doesn't typically lead to velvety skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Addison’s disease:

  • Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, leads to symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, salt craving, and hyperpigmentation. However, the hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's is more diffuse and not restricted to velvety changes in the axilla.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism:

  • This condition primarily results from an overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to elevated calcium levels in the blood. Symptoms include kidney stones, bone pain, and fatigue. Skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans are not a typical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References –

Harrisons principle s of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 390, 2933,2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3086, 3150, 3151, 3154, 3155, 3156, 3173, 3175

Current Medical Diagnosis & Treatment 2022 Page no 1157

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 147, Page no 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 391

questions.text: A suspect of sexual assault of 18 years of age claims to be of 16 years. X-rays of which area can confirm the correct age of the suspect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D)  Knee and wrist

 

To determine the accurate age of a person based on bone ossification, certain joints are examined through X-rays. The ossification of specific bones indicates different age groups. The wrist and knee typically ossify by the age of 18, while other joints, such as the elbow, ossify by the age of 16. In this case, the suspect is claiming to be 16 years old, but if X-rays of both the knee and wrist show full ossification, this would confirm that the suspect is actually 18 years old. This is because these areas would not be fully ossified at 16 but would be ossified at 18, matching the age of the suspect.

 

For 18 years of age:

 

 

For 16 years of age:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow and hip: The elbow and hip ossify by the age of 16. If these joints were ossified, it would support the suspect's claim of being 16 years old, which would not be useful in confirming that they are 18.

 

Option B. Elbow and wrist: The elbow ossifies at 16, but the wrist ossifies at 18. This combination would not be conclusive for determining that the suspect is 18 years old.

 

Option C. Knee and elbow: The elbow ossifies at 16, while the knee ossifies at 18. Similar to option B, this combination would be ambiguous and not definitive for confirming that the suspect is 18.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The ossification of the wrist and knee is a reliable indicator of whether an individual is 18 years old, as both these areas ossify by that age.

questions.text: Where will be the level of the uterus 48 hours after delivery?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2.5 cm below umbilicus

 

  • Following delivery, the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus
  • it remains at level of umbilicus for 24 hours. Following this, it involutes
  • It involutes 1.25 cm/ day form the 2nd day onwards
  • So, after 48 hours (2 days) post-delivery, the uterus will be felt 2.5 cm breadth below the umbilicus
  • It becomes a pelvic organ (no longer abdominally palpable) by 10-14 days
  • It becomes the size of a non-pregnant uterus by 6 weeks
  • alternatively, it reduces by 1 finger breadth / day from 2nd day post partum, till it becomes pelvic organ by 10-14 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterus will be 2.5 cm below umbilicus on the second-day post-delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 169, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

 

One of the most characteristic findings in respiratory distress syndrome is failure of the respiratory epithelium to secrete adequate quantities of surfactant, a substance normally secreted into the alveoli that decreases the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, therefore allowing the alveoli to open easily during inspiration.

 

The surfactant-secreting cells are type II alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. It appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

 

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 pneumocytes: Incorrect because although Type 1 pneumocytes cover a large surface area of the alveoli and are involved in the gas exchange process, they do not produce surfactant. The defect in Type 1 pneumocytes generally leads to issues with the structural integrity of the alveolar walls, not surfactant deficiency.

 

Option C. Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: Incorrect as these cells line the alveolar capillaries and are involved in the blood-air barrier for gas exchange. Defects in these cells can lead to issues like pulmonary edema but are not directly related to surfactant production or respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Option D. Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: Incorrect because these cells line the bronchial passages and are primarily involved in mucous production and the removal of particulates and pathogens from inhaled air. They are not involved in surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

 

The image represents a capnography waveform, which displays the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air. Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the period during exhalation where CO2 levels plateau as alveolar gas is exhaled. This phase reflects the CO2 concentration from the alveoli, which is relatively stable until the end of expiration. The end of phase III corresponds to the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), a key measurement in monitoring ventilation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the exhalation of alveolar gas and is used to determine the end-tidal CO2 level.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with breathlessness and cough. His recent CD4 count was less than 200 and the patient’s chest X-ray is shown. BAL was done and reports are pending. What is the likely diagnosis and treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumocystis jiroveci; Cotrimoxazole

 

The patient, an HIV-positive individual with a CD4 count of less than 200, presents with symptoms of breathlessness and cough. The chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. These findings are highly suggestive of Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), also known as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). This condition is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV infection.

 

The standard treatment for PJP is cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucor; Amphotericin B: Mucormycosis typically presents with necrotizing infection of the sinuses, brain, or lungs, often in diabetic or immunocompromised patients, but it does not typically present with the bilateral infiltrates seen in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Aspergillus; Voriconazole: Aspergillosis often presents with focal infiltrates or cavitations rather than diffuse bilateral infiltrates. It is also less common in patients with HIV compared to PJP.

 

Option D. Candida; Fluconazole: Pulmonary candidiasis is rare and usually occurs in severely immunocompromised patients, often presenting with multiple nodular infiltrates rather than the diffuse pattern seen in PJP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an HIV patient with a CD4 count less than 200, presenting with breathlessness and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, the likely diagnosis is Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), and the treatment of choice is cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: 52-year-old man collapses and you are giving CPR with your friend. What is the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult life support, the standard ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers. This ratio ensures that there is an adequate number of compressions to maintain circulation, while also providing necessary breaths to maintain oxygenation

 

In pediatric Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS), the ratio can vary depending on the number of rescuers. If there is only one rescuer, the ratio remains 30:2. However, if there are two rescuers, the ratio can change to 15:2.

For neonates, the ratio is different, typically 3:1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adult CPR, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is always 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

 

Lignocaine 2% (also known as lidocaine) is the most commonly used local anesthetic for cataract surgery. It provides effective and rapid onset of anesthesia, making it ideal for this type of procedure. Lignocaine is typically used for infiltration anesthesia, which involves injecting the anesthetic around the eye to block nerve impulses.

 

Types of Local Anesthesia:

 

  • Infiltrating Type: This involves injecting the anesthetic directly into the tissue to numb a specific area.
  • Topical: Applied directly to the surface of the skin or mucous membranes. Best drug is proparacain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine 0.5%:  While bupivacaine can be used in ophthalmic surgery, it's generally reserved for cases where longer-lasting anesthesia is required. It's not the first choice for routine cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Prilocaine 0.5%:  Prilocaine is sometimes used in dental procedures but is not commonly used in ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option D. Ropivacaine 0.05%:  Ropivacaine is used in various surgical procedures but is not typically the first choice for cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lignocaine 2% is the standard local anesthetic used in cataract surgery due to its rapid onset and appropriate duration of action. However, it's important to note that topical anesthesia using proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2 concentration

 

Methods to confirm endotracheal intubation:

  • X-ray chest
  • Auscultation
  • End-tidal CO2 concentration
  • Chest rise

 

This is considered the best method to confirm ETT placement in real-time. Capnography measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the exhaled breath. When the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea, it will produce a waveform with a consistent and relatively high end-tidal CO2 concentration. In contrast, if the ETT is in the esophagus or there is an airway obstruction, the end-tidal CO2 concentration will be lower or absent, providing immediate feedback to the anesthesiologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray chest: While a chest X-ray can confirm the placement of the ETT, it is not a practical or immediate method for confirming tube placement during intubation. X-rays are typically used for confirmation after intubation.

 

Option B. Auscultation: Auscultation involves listening to breath sounds over the chest and epigastrium to assess tube placement. While it can be a useful method, it may not always be reliable, especially in noisy clinical environments, and it may not detect esophageal intubation or partial airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Observing chest rise can be helpful, but it is not as reliable as capnography. In some cases, chest rise may be present even if the ETT is incorrectly placed in the esophagus, especially in cases of esophageal intubation with positive-pressure ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gold standard for confirming ETT placement is indeed the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography.
  • It provides real-time feedback and is considered a more reliable method compared to other options, ensuring that the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea and the patient is being ventilated effectively.

questions.text: A patient presents with linear nodular lesions extending along the lymphatic drainage after sustaining a rose thorn injury. Examination reveals a chain of linear subcutaneous granulomas. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schenckii

 

A history of a rose thorn prick followed by linear subcutaneous granulomas is highly suggestive of Sporotrichosis also known as "rose gardener's disease."which is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. This is a dimorphic fungus commonly associated with gardening injuries, particularly from rose thorns. The infection typically follows a lymphocutaneous spread, forming a chain of nodules along lymphatic drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: Characterized by chronic verrucous skin lesions and copper-colored sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) in tissue, typically due to traumatic implantation of fungi.

 

Option C. Nocardia: Causes cutaneous or pulmonary nocardiosis, which often presents with abscess formation but does not follow a linear spread along lymphatics.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Causes Blastomycosis, a systemic fungal infection that primarily affects the lungs and disseminates to the skin and bones but does not present with lymphocutaneous nodular spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is a subcutaneous fungal infection commonly acquired through traumatic inoculation, such as a rose thorn prick. It presents as lymphocutaneous nodular lesions that spread along lymphatics in a linear pattern. Diagnosis is confirmed by culture on Sabouraud’s agar, and treatment is typically oral itraconazole for mild cases or amphotericin B for severe infections.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

 

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication of CSOM.

 

Localizing symptoms of temporal lobe abscess -

 

  1. Nominal aphasia. If abscess involves dominant hemisphere, i.e. left hemisphere in right-handed persons, patient fails to tell the names of common objects such as key, pen, etc. but can demonstrate their use.
  2. Homonymous hemianopia. This is due to pressure on the optic radiations. Visual field, opposite to the side of the lesion, is lost. It can be elicited by confrontation test, by standing in front of the patient and comparing his visual field with that of the examiner, or by perimeter. The defect is usually in the upper, but sometimes in the lower quadrants.
  3. Contralateral motor paralysis. In the usual upward spread of abscess, the face is involved first followed by the arm and leg. Inward spread, towards the internal capsule, involves the leg first followed by the arm and the face.
  4. Epileptic fits. Involvement of uncinate gyrus causes hallucinations of taste, and smell and involuntary smacking movements of lips and tongue. Generalized fits may occur.

 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.

 

Management:

 

  1. IV antibiotics (usually third generation cephalosporin +/- metronidazole) are started. Aminoglycosides are added if pseudomonas infection is suspected. Culture and sensitivity of ear swabs can guide antibiotic therapy.
  2.  Raised intracranial tension can be lowered by dexamethasone, 4 mg i.v. 6 hourly or mannitol 20% in doses of 0.5 g/kg body weight
  3. Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Would likely present with different symptoms, including severe dizziness, balance problems, and coordination difficulties.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Usually presents with more diffuse cerebral symptoms and different radiological features.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Characterized by severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia, with different findings on lumbar puncture and imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of chronic ear infections that requires prompt recognition and aggressive treatment to prevent further neurological damage and potential life-threatening complications.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 90, 91

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient? ( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1c

 

T1c: Correct. T1c is for tumors > 2 to ≤ 3 cm in size, which matches the patient's tumor size of 2.5 cm.

 

According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm is staged as T1c.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2b: Incorrect. T2b is used for tumors > 4 to ≤ 5 cm in size.

 

Option C. T2a: Incorrect. T2a is for tumors > 3 to ≤ 4 cm in size.

 

Option D. T1a: Incorrect. T1a is for tumors < 1 cm in size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TNM staging system for lung cancer uses tumor size and extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M) to classify the disease. A tumor measuring 2.5 cm is classified as T1c according to the TNM 8th edition criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered the most sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community. IMR reflects the overall health and well-being of infants and the quality of maternal and infant care services. It is a comprehensive measure that can indicate various aspects of public health, including nutritional status, access to medical care, public health practices, and the socio-economic conditions of the community.

 

IMR = (Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births) × 1000.

 

SRS 2022-23 Latest data

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text:
A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)

 

RBS → 550

рН → 7.01

Na+ → 158

Urine glucose → 3+

Urine Ketone → +ve
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis

 

According to the ISPAD guidelines shown below, first the patient has to be classified for shock/Moderate dehydration/minimal dehydration. In this given scenario, child is in shock, so, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) and fluid replacement along with an IV bolus of 20 mL/kg 0.9% Normal saline, followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg/hr, 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr.: First we will give fluids and then after one hour we will give insulin

 

Option C. Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr: The fluid volume of 10 mL/kg is insufficient for severe dehydration and shock. The correct volume is 20 mL/kg.

 

Option D. Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour: This option provides an insufficient fluid volume and delays insulin administration, which is not recommended in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

questions.text: A mother with gestational diabetes gave birth. The newborn has jitteriness, poor feeding and crying episodes. Which is likely to be seen in the fetus? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoglycemia

 

In infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes, hypoglycemia is a common complication. During pregnancy, the high maternal glucose levels cause increased insulin production in the fetus. After birth, when the constant glucose supply from the mother stops but the infant's insulin levels remain high, hypoglycemia develops. The classic clinical manifestations include:

 

  • Jitteriness
  • Poor feeding
  • Excessive crying
  • Lethargy
  • Seizures in severe cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neonatal Sepsis:

 

  • While neonatal sepsis can cause similar symptoms, it is not directly related to maternal gestational diabetes
  • Would typically present with additional signs like temperature instability and respiratory distress

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism:

 

  • Hypothyroidism in newborns presents with different symptoms like prolonged jaundice and constipation
  • Not a direct complication of gestational diabetes

 

Option D. VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect):

 

  • While diabetic mothers have increased risk of fetal cardiac anomalies, VSD would not cause the acute symptoms described
  • VSD typically presents with failure to thrive and respiratory symptoms

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk of developing hypoglycemia in the immediate postnatal period due to persistent hyperinsulinemia after birth, manifesting as jitteriness, poor feeding, and crying episodes.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

A microscopic agglutination test is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Leptospira interrogans is a spirochete with hook-shaped ends found in water contaminated with animal urine, causes Leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis - Flulike symptoms, myalgias (classically of calves), jaundice, photophobia with conjunctival suffusion (erythema without exudate)

 

 

Weil disease (icterohemorrhagic leptospirosis) - severe form with jaundice and azotemia from liver and kidney dysfunction, fever, hemorrhage, and anemia.

 

Laboratory tests - Leptospirae can be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence.

 

Serotype-specific tests - Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)

 

  • Rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospirae - specific IgM antibodies in human sera.

 

Treatment - Penicillin or IV ceftriaxone

 

  • Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. Presents as stepwise increase in fever, abdominal pain, and constipation.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test used to diagnose rickettsial infections. Presents as fever, rash, and headache.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test, aka the Monospot test, used to detect heterophile antibodies in case of infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).Presents as fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The microscopic agglutination test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in symptomatic individuals, especially those exposed to potentially contaminated water environments. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

choices.text: Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

A water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan pulse, is characterized by a rapid and forceful rise in pulse with a quick collapse. It is typically seen in aortic regurgitation. This phenomenon occurs due to the regurgitation of blood from the aorta back into the left ventricle during diastole, leading to an increased stroke volume and a subsequent forceful arterial pulse that collapses suddenly as the blood quickly flows back into the ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: In aortic stenosis, the pulse is described as pulsus parvus et tardus—'small and slow,' reflecting the reduced and delayed pulse wave due to the obstruction across the aortic valve.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation: When these two conditions coexist, the pulse is known as pulsus bisferiens, which is characterized by a double peak per cardiac cycle—not the rapid rise and fall typical of a water hammer pulse.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: In mitral regurgitation, the pulse may be described as hyperkinetic due to the increased volume load on the left ventricle, but it does not exhibit the rapid collapse seen in water hammer pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The water hammer pulse is a distinctive physical finding primarily associated with aortic regurgitation and is useful in the physical diagnosis of this condition. This type of pulse helps clinicians in the assessment of the severity and impact of valve dysfunction on the cardiovascular system.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: Normal commensal conjunctival flora are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staph. epidermidis

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common normal commensal flora found on the conjunctiva. This bacterium is typically found on human skin and mucous membranes, including the surface of the eye. It's important to note that while S. epidermidis is usually harmless, it can become opportunistic and cause infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or following eye surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staph. aureus:  While S. aureus can be found on the conjunctiva, it's not as common as S. epidermidis and is more often associated with infections rather than normal flora.

 

Option C. H. influenzae:  This is not typically considered part of the normal conjunctival flora. It's more commonly associated with respiratory infections and can cause conjunctivitis when present in the eye.

 

Option D. Strep. pneumoniae:  This bacterium is not typically part of the normal conjunctival flora. It's more commonly associated with respiratory infections and can cause serious eye infections when present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common normal commensal flora of the conjunctiva. It's crucial to manage this normal flora during eye surgeries to prevent postoperative endophthalmitis. The use of povidone-iodine in the immediate pre-operative period is considered the best practice for preventing endophthalmitis by reducing the population of normal commensal flora on the ocular surface.

questions.text: A child developed multiple skin eruptions/burns after exposure to sunlight. Which of the following is the likely defect present in her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nucleotide excision repair gene defect

 

The clinical scenario described is characteristic of xeroderma pigmentosum, a genetic disorder caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway.

 

This pathway is responsible for repairing DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight.

 

In xeroderma pigmentosum, the failure to repair UV-induced DNA damage leads to severe skin sensitivity, hyperpigmentation, multiple skin eruptions, and a significantly increased risk of developing skin cancers such as squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, and melanoma.

 

In this case:

 

  • The history of skin eruptions and burns after sun exposure is classic for xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • NER gene defects prevent the proper repair of DNA damage caused by UV light, leading to the symptoms observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mismatch repair gene defect: This defect is associated with Lynch syndrome and other cancers but is not typically related to sunlight-induced skin conditions.

 

Option C. Base excision repair gene defect: This pathway repairs small, non-helix-distorting base lesions in DNA but does not handle UV-induced damage specifically.

 

Option D. Recombination repair gene defect: Recombination repair is involved in repairing double-strand breaks and does not directly relate to UV light-induced damage seen in conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair gene, leading to severe sensitivity to UV light, skin eruptions, and an increased risk of skin cancers

choices.text: Give aspirin and discharge the patient

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the past 20 minutes. The ECG demonstrates ST-segment depression, and troponin levels are positive. What is the next best step in the patient’s management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give aspirin + clopidogrel

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI), characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain radiating to the arm
  • ST-segment depression on ECG
  • Positive troponins

 

Initial management follows the MONA-B protocol, and dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is the first step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin alone and discharge: Incorrect, as NSTEMI requires hospital admission and further evaluation

 

Option C. Thrombolysis: Contraindicated in NSTEMI (only indicated for STEMI)

 

Option D. Stress test: Contraindicated in acute coronary syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

NSTEMI management includes dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel), and thrombolysis is contraindicated.

questions.text: Identify this contraceptive: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lippe’s loop

 

Lippe’s loop is a type of non-medicated, first-generation intrauterine device (IUD). It is a plastic coiled device that was widely used in the 1950s and 1960s. It is characterized by its distinctive S-shaped loops, as seen in the image provided.

 

The Lippe's loop does not contain any medication or metal, distinguishing it from other types of IUDs like the Multiload, Mirena, and Copper T 380A, which have additional features or materials to enhance their contraceptive effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiload: This option is incorrect. The Multiload IUD has serrated edges and typically includes copper wiring on the stem to enhance contraceptive effectiveness.

 

 

Option C. Mirena: This is incorrect. Mirena is a hormonal IUD that releases levonorgestrel and appears white in color. It does not have the coiled shape seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Copper T 380A: This option is incorrect. The Copper T 380A IUD has copper wires on the branches and the main stem, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lippe’s loop is a non-medicated, coiled plastic IUD from the first generation of intrauterine devices.

questions.text: Which of the following psychological coping strategies is not considered a defense mechanism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Replacement

 

Defense mechanisms are unconscious psychological strategies used by individuals to cope with reality and maintain self-image. Among the options provided, rationalization, displacement, and regression are well-known defense mechanisms.

 

However, Replacement is not considered a recognized psychological defense mechanism. The term "replacement" might refer to various coping strategies or processes, but it is not classified as a defense mechanism in psychological theory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rationalization: This is a defense mechanism where individuals create a seemingly logical reason for irrational or unacceptable behaviors or feelings to avoid the true explanation.

 

Option B. Displacement: This defense mechanism allows a person to transfer feelings or reactions from the original object or person to a safer substitute. For example, someone angry at their boss might instead take out their frustration on a family member.

 

Option C. Regression: This occurs when an individual faced with stress retreats to an earlier developmental stage. For instance, an adult under stress might start behaving like a child, engaging in activities or behaviors typical of a younger age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Replacement" is not classified as a defense mechanism, whereas rationalization, displacement, and regression are recognized defense mechanisms used to protect oneself from anxiety or unacceptable impulses.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Water’s view

 

Occipitomental view is also called Water's view.

 

Water's view: The patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward.

 

Structures seen in Water's view are:

 

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's view - Typically used for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum.

 

 

Structures seen – 

Arcuate eminence

Superior semicircular canal

Mastoid antrum

Internal auditory canal

Tympanic cavity

Cochlea

External auditory canal

 

Clinical application – Acoustic neuroma, Petrositis

 

Option C. Law's view - Generally related to imaging of the shoulder or elbow, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stenver's view - A radiographic projection used primarily for detailed imaging of the mastoid process and middle ear structures.

Structures seen –

Arcuate eminence

Internal auditory meatus

Labyrinth with vestibule

Mastoid antrum

Cochlea

Entire petrous pyramid

 

 

Educational Objective:


Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia, which is more pronounced for liquids than solids. A barium swallow study is performed. Which characteristic radiological finding is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rat tail deformity

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia:

 

  • Young patient (25 years)
  • Dysphagia to both liquids and solids, with liquids being affected more
  • In achalasia, barium swallow characteristically shows a "bird beak" or "rat tail" appearance due to smooth tapering at the gastroesophageal junction with proximal dilation of esophagus
  • This appearance is due to failure of LES relaxation with preserved peristalsis in body of esophagus, which is the hallmark of achalasia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smooth filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests a benign mass/tumor 

 

Option C. Irregular filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests malignant mass causing infiltration of the esophageal wall

 

Option D. Corkscrew esophagus: Incorrect as this is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm where the primary symptom is chest pain rather than dysphagia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rat tail/bird beak appearance on barium swallow is characteristic of achalasia cardia, which presents with dysphagia to liquids more than solids.

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

 

  • The clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side and unstable vitals suggests tension pneumothorax.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  •  This pressure can shift the mediastinum, compromise venous return to the heart, and result in hypotension or shock.
  • Immediate needle decompression or needle thoracostomy is necessary, which involves inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line to relieve the trapped air and stabilize the patient.
  • The definitive management is tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.
  • The clinical findings suggest a tension pneumothorax. An immediate decompression is needed to prevent circulatory collapse by allowing trapped air to escape, which can stabilize the patient until a chest tube can be placed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV fluids for resuscitation: While fluid resuscitation is vital in the management of trauma patients, the priority in this scenario, given the clinical findings suggestive of tension pneumothorax, is to relieve the trapped air. While IV fluids can support the circulatory system, they won't address the primary problem, which is the tension pneumothorax. The priority in trauma management follows the Airway -> Breathing -> Circulation (ABC) protocol.

 

Option C. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation: Intubation and positive pressure ventilation can be dangerous in a patient with tension pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the tension pneumothorax by forcing more air into the pleural space, which can lead to rapid cardiovascular collapse. Addressing the tension pneumothorax with needle decompression or chest tube insertion should be prioritized before considering intubation.

 

Option D. e-FAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma): While e-FAST is a valuable tool in the trauma setting to quickly evaluate for the presence of free fluid (e.g., blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, or pleural spaces, it may not be the immediate choice when a patient presents with clear signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and is hemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention to relieve the tension is essential, and while ultrasound can confirm the presence of pneumothorax, in an unstable patient, clinical judgment and prompt action are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

choices.text: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Anuj has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erythromycin only

 

In this case, the close contact of the patient is a 3-year-old child who had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, most likely as the 4th dose (1st booster). Therefore, only erythromycin is needed for prophylaxis.

 

It is crucial to monitor all household contacts for 7 days and obtain cultures from their nose and throat. Regardless of immunization status, all contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis such as benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One booster dose: This is not necessary because the child had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, which should still provide adequate immunity.

 

Option B. Nothing as the child is already exposed: This is incorrect because close contacts need to be managed to prevent the spread of diphtheria, and antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended.

 

Option C. Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid: This option is for those who have received less than three doses of diphtheria toxoid or have an unknown vaccination history. Since Ajay has been recently vaccinated, only erythromycin is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When Additional Toxoid is Needed:

  • <3 doses total received
  • >5 years since last dose
  • Unknown vaccination history
     

For a close contact of a diphtheria patient who has received the diphtheria vaccination within the last five years, antibiotic prophylaxis with erythromycin is the appropriate management step.

questions.text: An elderly patient underwent investigations which revealed Hb 9 g/dL, TLC 50,000/mm³, ↑PT, ↑aPTT, low platelet count, and increased D-dimers. Which of the following is the likely gene affected in the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PML- RARA


The patient's presentation with anemia, elevated white blood cell count, prolonged PT and aPTT, low platelet count, and increased D-dimers is indicative of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

 

DIC is commonly associated with Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL), previously known as AML M3. APL is characterized by a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17, resulting in the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

This fusion disrupts the normal function of the retinoic acid receptor, blocking the differentiation of promyelocytes and leading to an accumulation of immature cells. APL is strongly associated with DIC due to the procoagulant activity of the promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCR-ABL: BCR-ABL is a fusion gene associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), resulting from the Philadelphia chromosome translocation (t(9;22)). It leads to unregulated tyrosine kinase activity, promoting proliferation of myeloid cells. It is not typically associated with DIC.

 

Option B. NPM: Nucleophosmin (NPM) mutations are associated with a subset of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) without recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities, often presenting with a normal karyotype. It does not typically present with the coagulation abnormalities seen in DIC.

 

Option D. Inv 16: Inv(16) is associated with a specific subtype of AML (AML M4Eo), which involves abnormal eosinophils and monocytic cells. While it is an important genetic alteration in AML, it is not specifically linked with the coagulation issues seen in APL and DIC.

 

Educational Objective:


APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene and is highly associated with DIC, which can be identified by a combination of bleeding tendencies and abnormal coagulation profiles.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for indirect inguinal hernia with mesh repair. The most commonly damaged nerve in this surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilio-inguinal nerve

 

During open surgery for indirect inguinal hernia repair, particularly when mesh is used, the ilio-inguinal nerve is at significant risk of being damaged. This nerve runs through the inguinal canal, where it provides sensory innervation to the skin of the upper thigh, base of the penis, and scrotum in males, and the mons pubis and labia majora in females. Due to its anatomical position, it is prone to injury or entrapment during surgical procedures in this area, leading to postoperative pain or numbness in its distribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve runs along the anterior surface of the psoas muscle and divides into genital and femoral branches. While it is in proximity, it is less likely to be damaged during typical open inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is located deeper and more laterally, beneath the inguinal ligament, and is not commonly affected during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

Option D. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve is located in the pelvis and provides motor and sensory innervation to the medial thigh. It is not involved in the inguinal region and is therefore unlikely to be damaged in hernia surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ilio-inguinal nerve is the most commonly damaged nerve during open surgery for indirect inguinal hernia repair, especially when mesh is used.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever, muscle pain, and jaundice after working in flooded fields. Laboratory tests reveal a positive microscopic agglutination test. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Leptospirosis

 

The clinical presentation and exposure history are classic for leptospirosis. The key diagnostic findings include:

 

  • Occupational exposure (farmer working in flooded fields)
  • Classic triad of fever, muscle pain, and jaundice
  • Positive microscopic agglutination test (MAT), which is the gold standard diagnostic test for leptospirosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Diagnosed using different serological tests, not MAT.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium infection: Does not typically present with acute jaundice and is not diagnosed using MAT. 

 

Option C. Bacillus infection: Not associated with exposure to flooded fields or diagnosed using MAT.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard diagnostic test for leptospirosis, which typically occurs after exposure to contaminated water or soil.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swelling in hand & wrist. Finger X-ray is given. Identify: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromatosis

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.
  • Medullary cavity, Metaphysical tumour

 

 

  • Most common tumour of bones of hand and feet
  •  5% premalignant
  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome. There are multiple enchondromas all over the body.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith (Calcified superficial veins) = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment: Extended Curettage + bone grafting

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple brown tumor. It has been reported that 2-5% patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have brown tumor (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Bone brown tumor secondary to primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is very rare, which is caused by massive secretion of PTH. First, a large amount of bone calcium is mobilized into blood, resulting in fibrous tissue hyperplasia in bone and leaky hemorrhage. Then, macrophage reactive hyperplasia resulted in phagocytosis of red blood cells and a large amount of hemosiderin is produced, thereby forming a brown nodule. The lesions are usually multiple, most commonly seen in ribs, clavicle, pelvis, long bones and mandibles while others are rare. The radiograph of brown tumor is often characterized by osteoporosis, thinning of cortical bone and multiple localized cystic bone destruction.

 

 

Option C. Multiple osteophytic growth. Osteophytes are cartilage-capped bony proliferations that most commonly develop at the margins of a synovial joint as a response to articular cartilage damage, as seen very commonly in degenerative joint disease. Central osteophytes can develop from cartilage lesions within a joint. They are considered a hallmark of osteoarthritis. Osteophytes may be confused with syndesmophytes and enthesophytes. Small osteophytes are sometimes referred to as osteophytic lipping.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows multiple enchondromas in the hand.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saphenous nerve

 

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

 

Saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve.

 

Sensory Distribution: The saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body and provides sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the leg down to the medial side of the foot.

 

Clinical Relevance: Injury to the saphenous nerve, particularly during varicose vein surgery given its proximity to the great saphenous vein, would result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve:  It is formed by the joining of branches from the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It supplies sensation to the lateral and posterior aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the sural nerve would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Superficial peroneal nerve:  Branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It provides sensation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage to this nerve would cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral aspect of the leg but not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: Another branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Its sensory distribution is limited and includes the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve would affect the sensation between the first and second toes and would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with abdominal pain. Evaluation revealed the presence of renal calculi and high PTH levels. What should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tc-99m Sestamibi

 

The patient has elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and renal calculi, which suggests primary hyperparathyroidism. The next step in the management of primary hyperparathyroidism is to localize the overactive parathyroid gland(s). This is most effectively done using a Tc-99m Sestamibi scan. The Sestamibi scan helps in identifying the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland by detecting increased uptake of the radioactive tracer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound thyroid: While useful for identifying thyroid nodules, ultrasound thyroid is not the best tool for localizing hyperactive parathyroid glands in primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. DEXA scan: DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) scan is used to assess bone density and diagnose osteoporosis. While osteoporosis can be a consequence of hyperparathyroidism, the DEXA scan is not used to localize the hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine uptake study:  This study is used primarily for evaluating thyroid function, particularly in cases of primary hyperthyroidism, to determine the pattern of iodine uptake in the thyroid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with primary hyperparathyroidism indicated by high PTH levels and renal calculi, a Tc-99m Sestamibi scan is the appropriate next step to localize the overactive parathyroid gland(s).

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The marked area in the spirometry graph indicates the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC). FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation. This is not fully expelled during a standard tidal cycle and represents the air that remains in the lungs to keep them inflated.

 

  • FRC Components:
    • FRC includes the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) plus the Residual Volume (RV).
    • ERV is the additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after the end of a normal, calm exhalation.
    • RV is the volume of air still remaining in the lungs after the most forceful exhalation, which cannot be voluntarily expelled.

 

 

Significance in Spirometry:

 

In spirometry:

 

  • FRC is critical for maintaining the alveolar inflation and preventing the airways from collapsing.
  • It is not directly measurable by simple spirometry because it includes the residual volume. Techniques such as body plethysmography or using tracer gas dilution methods are usually employed to measure FRC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tidal Volume (TV or VT): This is the volume of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breathing cycle, not indicated in this context.

 

Option C. Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): Part of FRC, this is the maximum volume of air that can be voluntarily expelled after the end of a normal, passive exhalation.

 

Option D. Expiratory Capacity: It is the total amount of air that can be expired from the lungs after a maximal inhalation, typically including the tidal volume plus the expiratory reserve volume, not specifically marked here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration and is essential for preventing lung collapse and maintaining pulmonary function, especially during physical activities or respiratory challenges. Understanding FRC's role helps in assessing lung health and diagnosing potential respiratory disorders.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

choices.text: Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse
Reduces CO2 in alveoli
Decreases inspiratory pressure
Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output

questions.text: In a patient on mechanical ventilation and placed in prone position which of the following about PEEP is true? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse

 

Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is a crucial component of mechanical ventilation, particularly in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or other conditions leading to alveolar collapse. PEEP works by maintaining a certain amount of pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration, which helps to keep the alveoli open, preventing their collapse (atelectasis). This is especially important in the prone position, where the distribution of ventilation can be more uniform, improving oxygenation and lung mechanics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces CO2 in alveoli: This option is incorrect because the primary role of PEEP is not to reduce CO2 levels in the alveoli but to prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. CO2 removal is more dependent on ventilation rate and tidal volume.
